fields.name: Alexander Flemming
fields.text: In his Nobel lecture on 11 December 1945 he briefly mentioned lysozyme, saying, "Penicillin was not the first antibiotic I happened to discover." It was only towards the end of the 20th century that the true importance of Fleming's discovery in immunology was realised as lysozyme became the first antimicrobial protein discovered that constitute part of our innate immunity.

fields.name: Leonhard Euler
fields.text: Euler is held to be one of the greatest mathematicians in history and the greatest of the 18th century. A statement attributed to Pierre-Simon Laplace expresses Euler's influence on mathematics: "Read Euler, read Euler, he is the master of us all."

fields.name: Albert Einstein
fields.text: Albert Einstein is a physicist. He was successively German, stateless, Swiss and then Helvetic-American. He is one of the greatest scientists of humanity. He revolutionised mechanics with his theory of "general relativity". It states that gravitation is due to the curvature of space-time. It predicts the expansion of the universe, gravitational waves, black holes and the deflection of light by massive bodies such as black holes. He received the Nobel Prize for his work on the photoelectric effect. He is also well known for his equation E=mc2, establishing a relationship between mass and energy. As a child he was rebellious and was considered a bad student. In 1933, his house was looted by the Nazis and he decided not to return to Germany. His name and person are synonymous with intelligence and knowledge.

fields.name: Srinivasa Ramanujan
fields.text: During his short life, Ramanujan independently compiled nearly 3,900 results (mostly identities and equations). Many were completely novel; his original and highly unconventional results, such as the Ramanujan prime, the Ramanujan theta function, partition formulae and mock theta functions, have opened entire new areas of work and inspired a vast amount of further research.

fields.name: Winston Chruchill
fields.text: Sir Winston Churchill, born Winston Leonard Spencer-Churchill, is a British statesman. He is best known for leading the United Kingdom during the Second World War. He was Prime Minister from 1940 to 1945 and again from 1951 to 1955. He is also famous for his oratorical skills and his bon mots. With no personal fortune, he made his living as a journalist and writer, for which he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature. He was also an artist: painting was his main hobby.

fields.name: Catherine the Great
fields.text: Catherine II was a tsarina of Russia and the ancestor of the present House of Romanov. It is difficult to imagine a more diverse and seemingly contradictory character than Catherine II. Romanesque as much as realistic, an example of an "enlightened leader" for some, a tyrant for others, this sovereign knew better than anyone how to combine greatness and smallness. Considered by her contemporaries to be "one of the best heads in Europe" (Diderot), she devoted herself passionately, as she said, to her "job" as empress and deserved to be called, in spite of everything, "the sentinel who is never relieved. In fact, few monarchs worked harder for the greatness of their country than this princess, a stranger - by blood and culture - to her adopted homeland. She went down in history as the "Great Catherine". During her reign, Russia (the Russian Empire) expanded its European territory to the west and south (more than 500,000 km2 ), thanks to the partition of Poland and a series of victories against the Ottoman Empire.

fields.name: Peter I The Great
fields.text: Already during his lifetime, Peter the Great aroused both admiration and criticism. Some called him an "antichrist", others a creative hero. After his death, he was at the centre of all discussions on Russian history. Catherine II constantly referred to her glorious predecessor. In the 19th century, conservatives blamed him for creating a social divide in the Russian world by separating the "Europeanised" nobility from a people who had remained in an essentially religious tradition. But when Russia was in danger, during the Napoleonic invasion in 1812 and the Hitler invasion in 1941, historians evoked the image of the patriotic tsar, devoted to the independence and grandeur of the state. And if in the early days of the Bolshevik revolution the emphasis was on the harshness of the ruthless dictator who spared neither the blood nor the sweat of his subjects, very quickly a more impartial portrait emerged, recognising both the faults and the qualities of the man, as well as the positive character of his work. Iconography, statuary and academic competitions have perpetuated the image of Peter the Great in his most diverse activities. The statue of Falconet, erected under Catherine II, near the Winter Palace, to the glory of the reforming tsar (1782), shows him indicating with an imperious gesture the site of his capital; the poet Pu�kin dedicated his "Bronze Rider" (1833) to him: "Standing on the edge of the deserted waters, his mind full of great thoughts, he looks into the distance...".

fields.name: Ivan the Terrible
fields.text: In the history of ancient Russia, it is difficult to find a more controversial figure than Ivan IV. A bloodthirsty tyrant for some, he is considered by others to be one of the men who contributed most to the greatness of his country. There was a pathological element to his character that eventually degenerated into demented cruelty. The circumstances of his childhood had awakened in him a sickly distrust, a kind of nervous fear, a permanent state of irritation and a silent resentment against all beings: as a young man he had already lost his moral balance forever. But he was also one of the most educated men of his time, artistic, imaginative, hypersensitive; he astonished his contemporaries with his extraordinary gifts and the breadth of his political views. The little people always loved Ivan, who nevertheless made them suffer a lot; they venerated his memory and composed epic songs in his honour. It is the great ones who disgraced him, because they feared him; it is by the word "formidable" rather than "terrible" that the epithet of grozny which remains attached to his name should be correctly translated. To commemorate his victory over the Kazan Tatars, he had the famous St. Basil's Cathedral erected on Red Square.

fields.name: Jeanne d'Arc
fields.text: known as "La Pucelle", born around 1412 in Domr�my, a village in the Duchy of Barn 1 (now in the Vosges department of Lorraine), and died at the stake on 30 May 1431 in Rouen, capital of the Duchy of Normandy, then an English possession, was a heroine of French history, a war leader and a saint of the Catholic Church, posthumously nicknamed "La Pucelle d'Orl�ans".  At the beginning of the 15th century, this young girl from a peasant background claimed that she had been given the mission by Saints Michael, Margaret of Antioch and Catherine of Alexandria to deliver France from English occupation. She managed to meet Charles VII, lead the French troops victoriously against the English armies, lift the siege of Orleans and lead the king to the coronation in Reims, thus helping to reverse the course of the Hundred Years' War.  Captured by the Burgundians at Compi�gne in 1430, she was sold to the English by Jean de Luxembourg, Count of Ligny, for the sum of ten thousand pounds. It was condemned to be burnt alive in 1431 after a trial for heresy conducted by Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais and former rector of the University of Paris. This trial was marred by numerous irregularities and a review was ordered by Pope Calixtus III in 1455. A second trial was held in 1456, which concluded that Jeanne was innocent and fully rehabilitated. Thanks to these two trials, the minutes of which have been preserved, she is one of the best known personalities of the Middle Ages. known as "La Pucelle", born around 1412 in Domr�my, a village in the Duchy of Barn 1 (now in the Vosges department of Lorraine), and died at the stake on 30 May 1431 in Rouen, capital of the Duchy of Normandy, then an English possession, was a heroine of French history, a war leader and a saint of the Catholic Church, posthumously nicknamed "La Pucelle d'Orl�ans".  At the beginning of the 15th century, this young girl from a peasant background claimed that she had been given the mission by Saints Michael, Margaret of Antioch and Catherine of Alexandria to deliver France from English occupation. She managed to meet Charles VII, lead the French troops victoriously against the English armies, lift the siege of Orleans and lead the king to the coronation in Reims, thus helping to reverse the course of the Hundred Years' War.  Captured by the Burgundians at Compi�gne in 1430, she was sold to the English by Jean de Luxembourg, Count of Ligny, for the sum of ten thousand pounds. It was condemned to be burnt alive in 1431 after a trial for heresy conducted by Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais and former rector of the University of Paris. This trial was marred by numerous irregularities and a review was ordered by Pope Calixtus III in 1455. A second trial was held in 1456, which concluded that Jeanne was innocent and fully rehabilitated. Thanks to these two trials, the minutes of which have been preserved, she is one of the best known personalities of the Middle Ages.

fields.name: Hypatie
fields.text: Hypatia was a Greek neoplatonist philosopher, astronomer and mathematician from Alexandria. A woman of letters and science, she was the head of the Neoplatonic school in Alexandria, where she taught philosophy and astronomy. She was the first mathematician whose life is well documented. She is known during her lifetime as a renowned teacher and wise counselor. The only source listing her works, the Souda, attributes to her a commentary on the Arithmetics of Diophantus of Alexandria, which may have partially survived as part of Diophantus' original text, and a lost commentary on the treatise of Apollonius of Perga on conic sections. She also participated in the commentary or edition of Ptolemy's Almagest by her father. She also instructed other philosophers in the art of building astrolabes and hydrometers.  Although not a Christian, Hypatia was known for her tolerance of the early Christians. She taught many Christian students, including Snesios of Cyrene, the future bishop of Ptolemais. Until the end of her life, Hypatia advised Orestes, then prefect of Egypt, who was in open conflict with Cyril, bishop of Alexandria. Rumours that she was fostering conflict between Orestes and Cyril prompted a mob of Christian monks in March 415 to murder her, dismember her and burn her body. In particular, they were incited to kill Hypatia by a spiritual leader named Peter, under the influence of Cyril of Alexandria.  Her death at the hands of the Christians shocked the Empire and made her a 'martyr of philosophy', leading future Neoplatonists like Damascios to become fervent opponents of Christianity. During the Middle Ages, the symbol of Hypatia was reclaimed and distorted as an embodiment of Christian virtues; she may have been the origin of the legend of Catherine of Alexandria. During the Enlightenment, she again became a symbol of opposition to Catholicism. She became part of European literature under the impetus of Charles Kingsley in 1853, who wrote a novel about her life, and in the 20th century she became an icon of the women's rights movement and feminism. Many descriptions link her death to the burning of the Great Library of Alexandria, but the evidence shows that the two events are separate.

fields.name: Victoria
fields.text: Queen Victoria, who came to the throne in 1837 and died on 22 January 1901, symbolised the United Kingdom at the height of its power. The "Victorian era" thus sums up the success and ambiguities of England in the second half of the 19th century. The country was spared wars and revolutions, while at the same time carving out the world's first colonial empire (Victoria reigned over an empire "on which the sun never sets"); the Royal Navy and the City of London are the symbols of a success story that is primarily economic, based on the trilogy of steel, coal and cotton. Victoria was the queen of the world's leading industrial and commercial power. She was also the queen of the oldest parliamentary system in Europe, which was then considerably democratised and led by conservatives (such as Disraeli) and liberals (such as Gladstone). However, royal prerogatives were largely curtailed during her reign, and the Queen, who died in 1901, had less power than ever in England. She also left her name to a 'Victorian' society and morality, which combined the most glaring social inequalities with the strictest intellectual conformity.

fields.name: Marie Antoinette
fields.text: Marie-Antoinette Jos�phe Jeanne de Habsbourg-Lorraine, was Queen of France and Navarre from 1774 to 1791, then Queen of the French from 1791 to 1792. She was the last queen of the Ancien R�gime. Archduchess of Austria, Imperial Princess and Royal Princess of Hungary and Bohemia, she was the second last child and youngest daughter of Empress Maria Theresa of Austria and Francis I, Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. She became Dauphine of France in 1770, at the age of fourteen, through her marriage to the future King Louis XVI, then Queen of France in 1774, when her husband ascended the throne. After eight years of marriage, she gave birth to Marie Th�r�se, the first of her four children. She lost popularity due to accusations of sympathy with France's enemies, particularly her native Austria, and the affair of the necklace, where she was found to be the victim of a swindle. Demeaning nicknames, such as "l'Autrichienne" or "Madame D�ficit", circulated. Like her husband, she did not appreciate the constraints of the court and liked to spend time on her own, especially in the Queen's hamlet. At the beginning of the French Revolution, she was placed under house arrest in the Tuileries Palace, along with the royal family. Her attempted escape from Varennes in 1791 and her role in the war of the First Coalition further damaged her image. In 1792, the royal family was imprisoned in the Temple prison and the monarchy abolished. While Louis XVI was executed on 21 January 1793, the Queen's trial before the Revolutionary Court opened on 14 October; two days later she was convicted of high treason and executed by guillotine.

fields.name: Elizabeth 1 of England
fields.text: Under Elizabeth I, the small kingdom of England, surrounded to the north by an independent and hostile Scotland, to the west by an uncontrolled Ireland, and on the continent by the rise of the great absolutist monarchies of Spain and France, revealed itself, in the course of dramatic events, as a major partner in the European and world adventure. England asserted a personality that had matured during the Hundred Years' War, and was then forged by the masterly hand of the first Tudor kings. Shaped in turn by the cunning tenacity of Henry VII, then by the calculated outbursts of Henry VIII, it developed the social and economic foundations of its young power. The decline of feudalism, accelerated by government action, brought new actors onto the national scene: industrialists, merchants and 'adventurers' who gained strength at the expense of the old leaders of the political and economic game, the nobility and the Church. At the same time, the spiritual physiognomy adapted to the changing social structures; Henry VIII used his matrimonial adventures to break with Rome and place himself at the head of the Church of England, of which he controlled the episcopal body and secularised the monasteries. Encouraged by the "Henrician reformation", Protestant, Lutheran and soon Calvinist tendencies supplanted the old Catholicism, which had remained alive elsewhere, in government circles, in university and trading towns, and especially in London. Under the reign of Henry's successor, Edward VI, England moved decisively towards the Reformation, though not without sometimes strong resistance. Thus, original formulas were sought that would provide England with a religion adapted to the needs of its evolution. The Crown intended to free itself from Roman interference; but, despite their absolutist authoritarianism, the rulers were attentive to socio-economic trends and their spiritual corollaries. Parliament gained unparalleled influence by assuming supreme responsibility for the religious initiatives of Henry VIII and Edward VI. A new foreign policy also recognised the balance of power in Europe as the best way for England to participate as an arbiter in continental affairs, and especially in the increased exploitation of the major sectors of European trade. Society was undergoing profound changes, with the values of the "manorial system" already being challenged by those of urban, industrial and commercial capitalism, and the frenetic quest for money was combined with the taste for spiritual adventure that had long been expressed by so many learned and daring minds.

fields.name: Philip II of Spain
fields.text: Although Charles V enjoys a flattering reputation among historians, Philip II remains one of the most debated figures of modern times. Yet never was a son more concerned with continuing his father's work, with remaining faithful to his instructions. The Spanish king was deeply religious, sure of his rightful place and inclined to rigour.  The main features of his personality were a great capacity for work at the service of an average intelligence, a real shyness and a taste for solitude. Unlike Charles V, he behaved like a true Iberian, speaking only Castilian and Portuguese, and he never left the Peninsula after 1559. He was rid of the imperial title and the German wasp, and after 1581 he was master of two colonial empires, and was in fact more powerful than his father.  He did not like war, but allowed himself to be drawn into too many conflicts, in the Mediterranean against the Turks, in the Atlantic against England, in France against the supporters of Henry IV. The revolt in the Netherlands was the unhealable wound of the reign. The necessities of war forced Philip II to triple Castile's financial burdens. Was this the origin of the decadence? In part, no doubt. Recent research suggests that the epidemics of the late sixteenth and seventeenth centuries contributed as much.

fields.name: Anne Boleyn
fields.text: Second wife of King Henry VIII of England and mother of Queen Elizabeth I, born 1507, died 19 May 1536, London. The conditions of the annulment of Henry VIII's first marriage to Catherine of Aragon and his remarriage to Anne Boleyn led him to break with the Catholic Church and provoked the reformation of the English Church. Anne Boleyn's arrogant attitude soon earned her the enmity of the court. Although Henry VIII turned away from her and had affairs with other women, perhaps the birth of a boy could have saved their marriage. Anne Boleyn miscarried in 1534 and in January 1536 gave birth to a stillborn male baby. On 2 May 1536, Henry VIII had her imprisoned in the Tower of London for adultery with several men and incest with her own brother. She was unanimously found guilty by a court of peers and beheaded on 19 May. On 30 May, Henry VIII marries Jane Seymour. Anne Boleyn probably dies innocent, probably the victim of a court faction supported by Thomas Cromwell.

fields.name: Sappho
fields.text: A Greek poetess, Sappho, or more precisely in Aeolian Psapph� or Psapph�, belonged to a noble family from Mytilene, on the island of Lesbos. Her father was called Scamandronyme and her brother Charoxus. Banished around ~ 600, she was exiled to Sicily and then returned to her native country to end her days there. Ovid, in the Eroids, depicts her as 'small and black', while Alceus, who may have loved her, speaks of a 'pure Sappho, with braids of violets and a smile of honey'. She was also the head of a sort of religious brotherhood where young noblewomen, destined to take part in the ceremonies of the local cults, learned to sing, dance, play the lyre and read the poets. Her marriage to Cercolas or Cercylas is an invention of the Athenian comic poets: in fact, it seems that she did not marry. Her unhappy love for Phaon, for whom she threw herself into the sea from the rock of Lefkada, is also legendary. Sappho's name is still associated with the idea of homosexual love. Despite the opinion of many critics who have argued for her 'virtue' by pointing to the dignity of her response to the proposals of Alceus, her concern for her brother who was seduced by a courtesan, or her outbursts of maternal love, it is undeniable that Sappho's love poems are addressed to women. (And she sometimes names herself in them, which proves that they are not poems commissioned by lovers.) The thesis that there were two women: a vulgar courtesan and a distinguished poetess remains rather implausible.

fields.name: Nefertiti
fields.text: Nefertiti (whose name means "the beautiful one has come" or "the perfect one has arrived") was a Queen of Egypt, the great royal wife of Akhenaten, one of the last kings of the 18th Dynasty. Her beauty is legendary and it is certain that she played an important political and religious role during the Amarna period. Indeed, when a team of American archaeologists recently undertook a virtual reconstruction of the walls of the Temple of Aten at Karnak from talatates - a gigantic jigsaw puzzle of more than six thousand sandstone blocks removed from the Ninth Pylon - they were surprised to find that Nefertiti's depictions outnumbered those of Akhenaten, her royal husband. Elsewhere, the queen is depicted in the traditional pose of a pharaoh punishing Egypt's enemies, or officiating alongside the king before their god Aten. Other reliefs show the royal couple and the little princesses in their family intimacy. All these scenes are proof that the queen wielded considerable power, as official art has never before shown similar scenes.

fields.name: Marco Polo
fields.text: In the 13th century, Marco Polo, a Venetian merchant, embarked on a great journey to the East in the company of his father and uncle, in search of new commodities and new supply routes. He travelled through Turkey, Persia and above all China, where he stayed for twenty years. In the service of the Great Khan, as ambassador and governor, he travelled the country. As an attentive observer, he described the landscapes of Central Asia, collected legends, observed the daily life, customs and mores of the people he visited, and painted a fascinating picture of a kingdom where various religions coexisted peacefully. He evokes a country where gold and silk abound, but where a strange mineral and a viscous oil are also used, which will later be called coal and oil. And, above all, he paints an endearing portrait of an ideal emperor, the Great Khan Kubilai. Imprisoned in Genoa, the rival city of Venice, he dictated his memories to a fellow prisoner.

fields.name: William Shakespeare
fields.text: It would be fascinating to trace the curve of Shakespeare's reputation, for no other work, apart from the Bible, has attracted so much comment, so many scholars, so much controversy. But the consensus on the greatness and depth of the work is universal. Since the Folio that revealed this work to the world, its glory has not ceased to grow, so well established was it already among its own contemporaries.  Of course, every country and every era has its own Shakespeare. The eighteenth century began to establish the text, amended it and toned it down in places, sometimes adapting it to its own taste, and rewriting its plays by stripping them of their rough edges. In France, Voltaire was jealous of him, insulted him, but imitated him, or so he thought. Le Tourneur wraps it in the phraseology of the time with infinite precautions. Our Romantics adopt it and proclaim the revolution in its name. It was after the performances of Othello by an English troupe in Paris that Stendhal wrote his Racine et Shakespeare and exclaimed: "We must now have a theatre of our own. Victor Hugo idolises and mythologises him. He forced his son Fran�ois to undertake the translation of his complete works, for which he wrote his thunderous essay. Since then, Shakespeare has become part of the French consciousness in the same way as our own playwrights. He is the classic with which we can take all sorts of liberties. It is translated, adapted and performed in all sorts of ways. It has taken over our stages, it haunts our festivals, it has almost become one of ours. Anyone who doesn't have his Shakespeare is considered illiterate.  And yet, it is hardly after the inordinate efforts of Anglo-Saxon critics, to whom we are beginning to listen, that Shakespeare begins to emerge from the fog of contemporary passions in a guise that we would like to be his own. It is not enough to make Shakespeare a precursor of Kafka, a zealot of leftism before its time, or a structuralist sociologist. Gesticulation and vociferation are not enough to give him his true face either. Between Brecht and the Com�die-Fran�aise, even under the direction of an English director, there is room for a careful rereading and informed reflection.

fields.name: Aristotle
fields.text: Aristotle is an ancient Greek philosopher. He was a student of Plato and was influenced by Socrates. According to him, science can be theoretical, practical or productive. He wrote the Organon: a set of treatises in which logic is detailed and presented as a tool to advance science. He is considered the first to practice natural science. He discovered that dolphins are not fish, but mammals. He drew up a detailed description of the beehive which remained unchanged for over 2,000 years. He is the teacher of Alexander the Great, son of Philip II of Macedonia, who is his friend. He founded a philosophical school called the Lyceum. According to him, natural beings are made up of 5 elements: Earth, Water, Air, Fire and Ether. He demonstrated that the Earth is round.

fields.name: Plato
fields.text: Plato is an ancient Greek philosopher. He was the disciple of Socrates and the teacher of Aristotle. He is one of the first Western philosophers. His work is mainly composed of dialogues, almost all of which feature Socrates. He founded a school called the Academy, whose motto was: "Let no one enter here who is not a geometer". According to him, the soul is composed of 3 powers: appetite, anger and reason. He is a dualist: the soul and the body are completely separate. He distinguishes 5 political regimes: 1 perfect regime (Aristocracy) and 4 imperfect regimes (timocracy, oligarchy, democracy, tyranny). He establishes the theory of Forms: ideas really exist and constitute what we perceive. Plato tells the story of Atlantis: an island that existed around 9,500 BC and was technologically advanced.

fields.name: Jesus of Nazareth
fields.text: Jesus of Nazareth is a Jew from Galilee. He is a preacher, healer and exorcist. He presents himself as God's "vector". According to the New Testament, he is benevolent. His teaching focuses on love and forgiveness. He arouses the fervour of his disciples who see in him the son of God. He attracts the distrust of the political and religious authorities of the time. He had a last meal with his disciples (the "Last Supper") during which he announced his imminent death. He is arrested on the accusation of his disciple Judas and condemned for rebellion by Pontius Pilate. He was crucified in the year 30 in Jerusalem during the Jewish feast of the Passover. His disciples then announced his resurrection: this was the beginning of Christianity. Christianity is the most important religion in terms of numbers of followers. In Islam, Jesus of Nazareth is considered a major prophet.

fields.name: Socrates
fields.text: Socrates is an ancient Greek philosopher. He is the teacher of Plato. There is little certainty about him because he left no written records. His disciples often put him on stage in philosophical dialogues. According to the Pythia (the Oracle of Apollo at Delphi), he is the wisest man. He considers himself ignorant and often says: "I know only one thing, that I know nothing". He challenges others in public and then demonstrates their ignorance. He is known to have great physical strength. He is poor because he has few needs. He is sentenced to death because he does not worship the same gods as others. He is also accused of corrupting the youth. He dies by drinking poison at the age of 70.

fields.name: Alexander the Great
fields.text: Alexander the Great, King of Macedonia, was one of the greatest conquerors in history. His goal was to conquer the entire known world. His kingdom stretched from Greece, through the Middle East, to Egypt and India. He founded nearly 70 cities, almost all of which were called Alexandria. He was greatly influenced by Aristotle, his tutor. In particular, he took with him an edition of the Iliad, written by Aristotle, from which he derived his conduct. He is strong-willed and considers himself the son of God. He becomes king of Macedonia at the age of 20. He dies at the age of 32. A few days before his death, he is already very disabled. His soldiers believed him dead and demanded to see him. They parade before him, and he greets each of his men with a blink of the eye.

fields.name: Leonardo da Vinci
fields.text: Leonardo da Vinci is an Italian genius: he is an artist, scientist, inventor, anatomist, architect, town planner, philosopher and writer. He is considered one of the greatest painters of all time. He learned to read and write at the age of 12, and studied Greek and Latin at the age of 40. He was trained by Verrocchio, a famous painter, whom he quickly surpassed in all disciplines. At 26, he left his master and became an independent master painter. His two major works are the Mona Lisa and the Last Supper. They are known worldwide. He invented the submarine, the automobile, the calculator and the ball bearing. In 1516, Francis I invited him to France. He crossed the Alps at the age of 64 on a mule, carrying three major paintings: "Saint John the Baptist", "The Virgin, the Child Jesus and Saint Anne" and "The Mona Lisa". He died at the age of 67, of illness.

fields.name: Confucius
fields.text: Confucius is a great Chinese philosopher. He is the philosopher who has had the greatest impact on Chinese civilisation. He is considered the first "educator" of China. His main disciples are the Twelve Philosophers. They are honoured in Confucian temples. He has the largest family tree in the world with 83 generations and 2 million known descendants, out of an estimated 3 million. He is over 2 metres tall. His disciples have collected his words and thoughts in the "Confucius Talks". According to him, every man must become a "Junzi", a morally good man. On the other hand, he considered the "Sage" to be an unattainable ideal. His doctrine is Ren, which means benevolence. He teaches everyone, but mainly future men of power and the sons of princes.

fields.name: Julius Caesar
fields.text: Julius Caesar was a Roman politician. He extended the Roman Empire to the Rhine and the Atlantic Ocean and then took power in Rome with his army. He was ambitious, brilliant, a skilled strategist and tactician. He grew up in a poor neighbourhood, but received an exemplary education. At the age of 20, he joined the army and achieved great things. Back in Rome, he was elected pontifex, then became consul at 41. He conquered Gaul by taking advantage of the Helvetian migration in 58BC. In 52 BC, he won a decisive victory at the siege of Alesia, where he received Vercingetorix's surrender. In 49BC, he took up arms in Italy and crossed a river, the Rubicon: this was a declaration of war. He then said: "Alea jacta est" (the die was cast). In 44 BC, he was assassinated by 23 stab wounds. The final blow came from his son Brutus. When he saw him, he said: "Tu quoque mi fili" ("You too my son!").

fields.name: Homer
fields.text: Homer is said to have been a Greek poet. He is said to be the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, the first two works of Western literature. It is not known if he really existed or if he is a constructed identity. Homer may have been blind. It is also possible that he was a woman. His texts were poems, which favoured oral transmission. The Iliad is an ancient Greek epic about the end of the Trojan War, during which the Greeks and Trojans clash. It ends with the duel between Achilles (Greek) and Hector (Trojan) and the upcoming victory of the Greeks. The Odyssey is an epic about the adventures of Odysseus (Greek hero of the Trojan War) during which he meets many characters and gods of Greek mythology. It takes Odysseus 10 years to return home to his wife (Penelope) and son (Telemachus).

fields.name: Pythagoras
fields.text: Pythagoras was a Greek philosopher, mathematician and scientist.  He gave his name to a great mathematical theorem: the Pythagorean theorem. However, the results of this theorem were already known for 1000 years. The oldest known demonstration was made by Euclid (in 300BC). His name means "the one who was announced by the Pythia". He was the first person to call himself a "philosopher", i.e. "lover of wisdom". He took part in the Olympic Games at the age of 17 and won all the pugilistic events (ancestor of boxing). For him, numbers were very important and he developed a demonstrative mathematics. He is the founder of political science and defends the Aristocracy, just like Plato. Aristocracy is the government of an elite, in particular of scholars.

fields.name: Archimedes
fields.text: Archimedes of Syracuse was a Greek scientist from Sicily. He is considered one of the greatest mathematicians of humanity. He described Archimedes' buoyancy: the force experienced by any body immersed in a liquid. He was very interested in mechanics. Speaking of the lever effect, he said: "give me a fulcrum and I will lift the world". He works on infinity and says that the grains of sand are in finite number. Much of his work is about geometry. He is said to have shouted Eureka! ("I have found it!" in ancient Greek) while running naked through the streets of Syracuse after finding the solution to a complex problem. He had to check that a crown was made only of gold. In his bath, he realised that by weighing the crown, and measuring its volume by immersion in water, he could calculate its density and compare it to pure gold.

fields.name: Moses
fields.text: Moses is the first prophet of Judaism. For Jews and Christians, he is the author of the first 5 books of the Bible, the Pentateuch. He is the most prominent prophet in the Koran and foreshadows the prophet Mohammed. As a child, he was found in a wicker basket floating on the water and was adopted. He opposed the Egyptians who mistreated his people and had to flee into the desert where he became a shepherd. At the age of 80, he sees God in a burning bush who orders him to bring the Hebrews to the Promised Land. But Pharaoh refuses to let them go. God then unleashes 10 terrible plagues on Egypt and the Hebrews flee. Arriving at Mount Sinai, they receive the Decalogue (the 10 commandments). God punishes them to stay 40 years in the desert, because they disobey him.  Moses dies at the age of 120, at the gates of the Promised Land.

fields.name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah
fields.text: Muhammad is an Arab religious, political and military leader. He is the founder and prophet of Islam. He distinguished himself from people of his age by being a model of physical, intellectual and moral perfection. At the age of 40, he received the revelation, the word of God, from the archangel Gabriel. For 23 years, Gabriel dictated verses to him in Arabic. He founded Islam, whose believers would become Muslims. He performs several miracles: the moon splits in two, he makes rain fall and makes water gush out of his hands. Following a vision, he invites the faithful to pray facing Mecca and no longer Jerusalem. He conquers Mecca with 10,000 soldiers and its inhabitants convert to Islam. He has 7 swords, 3 bows, 3 breastplates, 3 spears and 1 shield. He dies in 632 in Medina, after several defeats and assassination attempts.

fields.name: Abraham
fields.text: Abraham is the founding father of the Jewish, Christian and Muslim religions. He is the initiator of monotheism, the ancestor of Judaism and Christianity.  He is also considered a great prophet in Islam. He is the main character in the book of Genesis. He was originally called Abram, and later became Abraham. He is called Ibrahim in the Koran. When he was 75 years old, God told him that he would give the land of Canaan to his descendants and ordered him to go there. When he was 100 years old he had a son: Isaac. When Isaac was a teenager, God ordered him to take him to Mount Moriah and sacrifice him. Once there, Abraham builds an altar to sacrifice his son. A messenger from God intervenes and tells him that he only wishes to test his faith. He dies at 175 in the land of Canaan.

fields.name: Adolf Hitler
fields.text: Adolf Hitler was a German politician born in Austria-Hungary. He is the main trigger of the Second World War. He lost it and Germany capitulated on 8 May 1945. He is considered as the absolute evil in the collective memory. In 1908, he failed at the school of fine arts due to lack of work. He created Nazism: a totalitarian and imperialist doctrine, based on biological racism and anti-Semitism. In 1923, after a failed coup d'�tat, he is thrown into prison and writes "Mein Kampf" in which he describes his racist theories. He was appointed Chancellor on 30 January 1933. On the night of 29-30 June 1934, he organised the physical elimination of his opponents. This is known as the night of the long knives. In August 1934, he was elected F�hrer with 85% of the German votes, which put an end to democracy and established a dictatorship.

fields.name: Joseph Stalin
fields.text: Of all the great politicians of the 20th century, Stalin was probably the one who had the longest impact on world affairs and the most profound transformation of his country. Churchill and Lenin had a major influence for only five years, Roosevelt and Hitler for twelve, while Stalin directly influenced the destiny of not only nearly two hundred million Soviets, but also an almost equal number of Europeans in the central and eastern part of the continent for a quarter of a century. Rarely has a politician aroused so much hatred and adoration. By the 1930s, Stalin had become an abhorred symbol for all those who fought communism, whether they were his closest competitors - the fascists and Nazis - or, on the contrary, whether they saw in the "Man of Steel" the embodiment of a new anti-humanism. But Stalin was also the object of a formidable cult, of a passion that was both revolutionary and messianic. If adoration was reserved for communist "believers", admiration for "Marshal Stalin" was widespread among non-communists; it was based on recognition of the victor of Stalingrad, who had largely contributed to the Allied victory over Nazi barbarism. A remarkable political strategist and tactician. Soviet society paid a particularly heavy price for the Stalinist model of transformation of the country: between 1930 and 1953, more than a million Soviets were sentenced to death as 'counter-revolutionaries' by a special court; seven million Soviets were deported, more than fifteen million experienced the Gulag labour camps, six or seven million died of hunger during two great famines (1932-1933; 1946-1947).  As the archives, declassified since 1991, have confirmed, the dictator played a decisive role in the elaboration and implementation of major political options, both on the domestic level (forced collectivisation of the countryside, accelerated industrialisation, purges and terror operations) and on the international level (anti-fascist turn and support for the "Popular Fronts" in the countries of parliamentary democracy from 1934-1935 onwards; the German-Soviet pact in August 1939; the definition of zones of influence in Europe in 1944-1945). The documents that are now accessible allow us to better identify the personal mark of the dictator in the management of the USSR and to analyse the way in which he exercised power.

fields.name: W. A. Mozart
fields.text: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart is an Austrian composer of music. He is considered a virtuoso on the piano and violin. At the age of 3, he already showed prodigious musical ability. His father taught him to play the harpsichord at the age of five, and he composed his first music at the age of six. At 14, he rewrote a complex work lasting 15 minutes, having heard it only once. The nobles treated him with condescension and his employer, Prince Archbishop Colloredo, regularly called him a moron and a rogue. He was finally dismissed and set up as an independent. He became a Freemason at the age of 28. He worked a lot and produced many works. He was in debt and often ill. He died at the age of 35 after having composed almost 900 works. Mozart became synonymous with genius and perfect mastery.

fields.name: Claudius Ptolemy
fields.text: Claudius Ptolemy was a Greek astronomer. He is one of the inventors of geography. He wrote several reference books such as the Almagest, the Geography, the Harmonics and the Optics. The Almageste is a book on astronomy that allows the precise prediction of the position of the stars. The almageste contains a list of 1'022 stars and 48 constellations. The almageste will remain a reference book for more than 1'300 years, receiving only minor corrections. The Geography is a book containing all the knowledge concerning the world at the time. The Harmonics is a reference book containing the mathematical principles of music. Optics is a book about the properties of light and a theory of vision.

fields.name: Nicolaus Copernicus
fields.text: Nicolaus Copernicus was a Polish astronomer, physician and mathematician. He invented the theory of heliocentrism, which states that the Sun is at the centre of the universe and that the Earth revolves around it. In contrast to geocentrism, this theory makes it easy to explain the observed movements of the planets, and to measure the distances of the planets from the Sun. He was a canon (a man of the cloth) His theories went against the beliefs of the time that the Earth was at the centre of everything. He kept his theory secret for 36 years out of scientific rigour. Indeed, he never managed to make it correspond perfectly to his observations. In 1543, at the time of his death, his theory of heliocentrism was published. His book was put on the Index (i.e. banned by the Church) in 1616 because it contradicted the theories of the time.

fields.name: Johannes Kepler
fields.text: Johannes Kepler was a German astronomer. He is famous for having studied the heliocentrism of Nicolas Copernicus. He discovered that the planets do not revolve around the Sun in circles but in ellipses and established three laws. These laws were used by Isaac Newton to describe the theory of universal gravitation. He was invited by Tycho Brahe to calculate the orbit of Mars. He thought it would take him a few weeks, but it took him 6 years. He invented the word Satellite (which means "Bodyguard" in Latin) to refer to the moons of Jupiter. He grew up in difficult circumstances with a mercenary father in the army and a mother he said was small, thin and quarrelsome. He was a precursor of science fiction and wrote a book about the perception of our world by a person on the moon.

fields.name: Tycho Brahe
fields.text: Tycho Brahe was a Danish astronomer. He broke with tradition by giving priority to observation and the validation of his hypotheses. His observations of the stars and planets were at least ten times more accurate than those of his predecessors in Europe. However, he made his observations with the naked eye and was the last astronomer before the invention of the telescope. He rejected the heliocentric system and preferred to establish a mixed system known as geo-heliocentric: the Earth is at the centre of the Universe, and the other planets revolve around the Sun. Johannes Kepler used his observations of the trajectory of Mars to find the laws describing the orbits of the planets around the Sun. He was also a pharmacist and created many remedies and elixirs. At the time of his death, he was the most popular scientist in Europe.

fields.name: Galileo Galilei
fields.text: Galileo was an Italian mathematician, physicist and astronomer. He revolutionised astronomy by improving the telescope. Thanks to the telescope, he discovered in particular the rings of Saturn and sunspots. He also conducted many experiments and laid the foundations of kinematics and dynamics. He is considered one of the founders of physics. He defended heliocentrism. This theory, being contrary to the religious ideas of the time, was eventually censored (banned). He tricked the Church into approving the publication of a book presenting geocentrism and heliocentrism in a neutral way. But he only shows the preface and conclusion. Once published, the Church discovered that it was a plea for Heliocentrism. The Church will heavily condemn Galileo.

fields.name: Isaac Newton
fields.text: Sir Isaac Newton is an English philosopher, mathematician, physicist and astronomer. He is one of the greatest geniuses in human history. He founded classical mechanics and discovered the theory of universal gravitation: the closer and heavier bodies are, the more they attract each other. Legend has it that he understood gravitation because an apple fell on his head. His theory of universal gravitation works in many situations but fails to explain the precession of Mercury's perihelion, black holes and the deflection of light by large masses such as stars and galaxies. He discovered, with the help of a prism, that white light is composed of a spectrum of coloured lights. He argued with Leibniz, another mathematician, about who was the first to discover infinitesimal calculus.

fields.name: Eratosthenes
fields.text: Eratosthenes was a Greek philosopher and mathematician. He is famous for using a purely geometric method to calculate the circumference of the Earth (which is about 40,000 km). He calculated an extremely precise value of 39,375 km, unlike Aristotle who had estimated it at about 60,000 km.  As a mathematician, he established the Eratosthenes sieve, which makes it possible to find, by successive elimination, all the prime numbers below a given integer. He is credited with inventing the word geography. He calculated the length of the arc of the meridian between the two tropics. This value was recalculated and validated 2,000 years later by the French Academy of Sciences. He eventually starved himself to death because, having become blind, he could no longer admire the stars.

fields.name: Johannes Gutenberg
fields.text: Johannes Gutenberg was a German inventor and printer. He improved printing and invented movable metal type. This work was crucial for the spread of books, texts and knowledge in Europe. He found his new printing method when he saw a wine press in Strasbourg in operation. In the Middle Ages, few people could read and books were rare. They were reproduced in monasteries by copyist monks. The illustrations were done by specialised monks, the illuminators. His new technique made it possible to produce 180 Bibles in 3 years: that's how long it takes a monk to copy one. At first he joined forces with a wealthy banker named Johann Fust, who financed his invention. But the printed Bibles did not sell well. He and Johann Fust sue each other, which he eventually loses and is ruined.

fields.name: Alan Turing
fields.text: Alan Turing was a British mathematician. His work founded computer science in a scientific manner. During the Second World War, he deciphered the Enigma machine, used by the German army to code their messages. To do this, he created a machine that could do the work of 10,000 people. This made it possible to decipher a message in 20 minutes, instead of 5 billion years if all possibilities had to be tested. Thanks to his work and discoveries, he shortened the war by two years and saved 14 million people. He invented the Turing machine. It is an abstract model of how computers work and defines, in particular, what an algorithm is. He invented the Turing test which allows to decide if a machine is intelligent or not by making it imitate human conversion.

fields.name: Euclid
fields.text: Euclid was an ancient Greek mathematician. He wrote "Elements of Mathematics". Composed of 13 books, it is one of the most important works in mathematics. It is remarkable for its deductive form and its systematic and progressive organisation. In this work, he starts by stating definitions (of a line, a prime number, etc.) and then deduces new properties. He also writes the "Pseudaria" ("spurious arguments"). This book teaches beginners how to detect reasoning that is false, but yet seems true. He gives examples of paralogisms (false reasoning that appears valid to its author) and sophistry (false reasoning used to deceive). He also looks at astronomy, optics, and music. There are no direct sources of information about Euclid's life.

fields.name: Herodotus
fields.text: Herodotus is a Greek historian. Cicero (a Roman politician) called him the "Father of History". He claimed to rival Homer. But rather than singing of past exploits, he prefers to describe very recent events. He is also considered one of the first geographers because he tells the stories of his travels. In particular, he helped to draw up the list of the seven wonders of the world: the pyramid of Cheops at Giza in Egypt, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon in Mesopotamia, the statue of Zeus at Olympia in Greece, the temple of Artemis at Ephesus in Greece, the mausoleum of Halicarnassus in Turkey, the colossus of Rhodes in Greece and the lighthouse of Alexandria in Egypt. He is interested in politics and writes a critique of the three major forms of government: democracy, aristocracy, and monarchy.

fields.name: Ada Lovelace
fields.text: Ada Lovelace is an English mathematician and computer scientist. She is considered the first female programmer in history. She is the daughter of Lord Byron, a famous English poet. Her mother loved mathematics and ensured that she received a thorough education in science. At 17, she met Charles Babbage. She marvelled at his analytical machines, a forerunner of the computer. While working on the translation of an article in French describing Babbage's analytical machine, she decided to add notes to it. One of these notes is a real algorithm. This algorithm is considered the first computer program in the world. A programming language, the Ada language, was named after her. Her portrait is visible on the authentication holograms of Microsoft products.

fields.name: Michelangelo
fields.text: Michelangelo was an Italian sculptor and painter. He is known to be an exceptional artist and superior to artists of his time such as da Vinci and Raphael. He was also an architect and designed the dome of St. Peter's in Rome, Italy. Before he was 30, he sculpted "David" and "La Piet�", two of the most famous marble sculptures in history.  During 4 very trying years, he painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. He is very influenced by Plato, which is very evident in his works. He continued to advise his students and remained active until his death at the age of 88.

fields.name: Tamerlan
fields.text: Tamerlane was a fourteenth-century Turko-Mongol warrior who conquered a large part of Central and Western Asia and founded the Timurid dynasty, which lasted until 1507.  He conquered a large part of Asia. He was an exceptional and much feared conqueror because he totally destroyed the cities that dared to resist him. He began his military career at the age of 16. Fearing a revolt in Samarkand (a large city in Uzbekistan), he had to flee. Several years later, he officially became ruler and took the throne in Samarkand and made it his capital.  As emir of Transoxiana, Tamerlane proved to be a formidable warlord, building an immense empire based on military power and terror. Historians often refer to his destruction and massacres as the 'Timurid catastrophe'; estimates of the death toll from his military campaigns range from 1 million3 to 17 million people (about 5% of the world's population at the time)4. During his conquests, he did not hesitate to massacre the entire population of the cities that resisted him, with the exception of the artisans, whom he deported to Samarkand, his capital. It was in this capacity that he also showed himself to be the protector of the arts and letters that made Samarkand great.  He spent the next 30 years waging war and launching expeditions and built the third largest empire in the world. In each conquered city, he recruited the best craftsmen and scientists and sent them to Samarkand.  After Tamerlane's death in 1405, his empire, ruled by his descendants (the Timurids), was nibbled away by neighbouring powers until a final assault by the Uzbeks of the Chaybanid dynasty.   He died of illness at the age of 68, during an expedition to China. His tomb is in the Gur Emir (a mausoleum) in Samarkand. A legend says that his tomb is cursed. It is inscribed: "When I return to the light of day, the world will tremble.

fields.name: Genghis Khan
fields.text: Genghis Khan (meaning "universal ruler"), originally named Tem�djin, was the first Mongol emperor. Thanks to his political and military genius, he succeeded in unifying the Mongolian and Turkic tribes of Central Asia, thus creating the largest empire of all time. The childhood of the man then called Tem�djin is little known. It is believed that he was born holding a bone-shaped blood clot in his fist. During his youth, the Mongolian clans were torn apart by internal conflicts and guerrilla wars. They were divided and weakened against their main rivals: the Turks and the Tatars. When the young Mongol was barely 10 years old, his father was poisoned during a meal shared with the Tatars. The clan did not submit to the authority of the child, who was too young, and it was the Ta�djioutes who seized power. The future Genghis Khan spent many years wandering around with his family.  At the age of 19, Tem�djin had already built up a reputation as a fierce warrior and a fine politician, enabling him to unify the various Mongolian tribes little by little. In 1201, allied with the Chinese, he defeated the Turks, Tatars and Tajiks in several resounding battles. Five years later, he was named universal ruler (Genghis Khan) by the Mongolian people, due to his numerous victories on the battlefield. Mongolia was born. The conquests towards the neighbouring kingdoms, especially China, then began. In 1220, the Mongolian empire extended to the Muslim kingdom of Khwarezm, stretching between the Caspian Sea and the Persian Gulf. After a final victorious campaign in China, Genghis Khan outlined his plans for the vast empire he had created to his youngest son. He died in 1227. His body was taken to a secret mausoleum in Mongolia.  He is considered the father of Mongolia and is now a legend. He established laws protecting women. After his death he is buried in a secret place that no one knows about. According to the legend, he is the descendant of a wolf, a wild hind and a woman impregnated by a ray of sunlight. He is also said to have killed a bear with his bare hands.
